Subjective: Back pain radiating down right leg to foot, worse on right side. Unable to sleep due to pain. No relief from paracetamol and ibuprofen. Works in supermarket, temporarily stopped working due to pain. No loss of strength in leg, slight numbness on outside of lower right leg, some tingling. No issues with sensation in riding breeches area or with urination/defecation.
Objective: No visible abnormalities in legs or back. No pain on palpation of vertebrae. Pain with straight leg raise on right side. Slight difference in sensation between left and right lower leg. Normal strength in both legs. Normal reflexes.
Assessment: Lumbosacral radicular syndrome, suspected herniated disc. No signs of cauda equina syndrome.
Plan: 1. Start pregabalin for pain relief, gradually increasing dose. 2. No driving for at least a week after starting pregabalin or if experiencing side effects. 3. Physiotherapy referral for exercises to improve back flexibility. 4. Follow-up phone appointment in one week to discuss pain relief progress. 5. Contact doctor or out-of-hours service if symptoms worsen, loss of sensation in riding breeches area, inability to feel need to urinate/defecate, or significant loss of strength in leg.
